title: A Random Walk Down Wall Street
author: Burton G. Malkiel
text: A blindfolded monkey throwing darts at a newspaper's financial pages could select a portfolio that would do just as well as one carefully selected by experts.

title: A Random Walk Down Wall Street
author: Burton G. Malkiel
text: The market is not always right. But no one person or institution can consistently know more than the market.

title: The Pragmatic Programmer
author: David Thomas, Andrew Hunt
text: Don't live with broken windows. Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

title: The Pragmatic Programmer
author: David Thomas, Andrew Hunt
text: Care about your craft. Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

title: Fundamentals of Software Architecture
author: Mark Richards, Neal Ford
text: Everything in software architecture is a trade-off. If an architect thinks they have discovered something that isn't a trade-off, more likely they just haven't identified the trade-off yet.

title: Fundamentals of Software Architecture
author: Mark Richards, Neal Ford
text: Why is more important than how. An architect should be able to explain why a particular architectural decision was made.

title: Deep Work
author: Cal Newport
text: High-quality work produced = Time spent Ã— Intensity of focus

title: Deep Work
author: Cal Newport
text: The ability to perform deep work is becoming increasingly rare at exactly the same time it is becoming increasingly valuable in our economy.

title: Man's Search for Meaning
author: Viktor E. Frankl
text: Those who have a 'why' to live, can bear with almost any 'how'.

title: Man's Search for Meaning
author: Viktor E. Frankl
text: Between stimulus and response there is a space. In that space is our power to choose our response. In our response lies our growth and our freedom.
